Simple debug log for C++

Fredrik Bornander
Rate me:
1
2
3
4
5
4.88/5 - 19 votes
4 removed
μ 4.52, σa 1.39 [?]
Please Sign up or sign in to vote.
4.88/5 (19 votes)
15 Mar 2010CPOL11 min read 129.1K   1.5K   49   30
An article on how to create a simple log for debugging applications.
  • Download source code - 5.37 KB

Introduction

In this article, I will discuss how to utilise deterministic destruction in C++ in order to create a simple debug log. The purpose of this log will be to show the flow of execution and the values of variables.

Update: This is the third version of this article. The article itself is unchanged, but the source project had some errors in its Release version (as pointed out by bilo81, thanks for that). These have now been fixed.

Before anyone goes off on a rant about how this is not a proper logging framework and how it is not supporting the most commonly found features of other logging frameworks such as log levels and multiple log destinations, let me reiterate that this is a simple debug log. The intention of this article is to describe a light-weight log utility used to provide information useful for debugging, not for application state logging. For an awesome full-fledged logging framework for C++, I'd suggest you check out this.

Background

In some utilities and console applications I've had to write, I've found myself sometimes running into issues only on a specific platform or under a certain configuration. In these cases, I've often not have had access to a debugger that I can attach to the process, and debugging and troubleshooting have therefore been difficult as just outputting the error does not provide enough information to fully diagnose the issue.

In these cases, I have resorted to using a utility similar to the one this article will discuss, something that can track a few vital things that enables me to pinpoint the problem and provide me with enough context to figure out what's wrong. The things I like to track are:

  • Method entry
  • Method exit
  • Call chain
  • Variable values
  • Exceptions thrown

By using some macros, these things can be outputted in a neat format, providing call chain context by indenting the output as the call stack gets deeper.

Using the code

As this is supposed to be something light-weight, the intention is to include the files DebugLog.hpp and DebugLog.cpp directly into the project you want to add debug logging to, rather than linking against a library.

Implementation

Overview

In order to enable and disable the logging using a pre-processor directive, macros are used for all logging statements. Normally, I'm not a big fan of macros because most of the macros I've seen, I believe, should have been implemented as methods instead, but in this case, they're not only a necessity, they also provide some neat functionality such as enabling the debug log to output the name of a variable.

Method entry and exit

In order to log method entry and exit, something has to be written to the log whenever a method is entered or exited. To log something on entry is easy, simply call the the appropriate log method as the very first thing of every method:

C++
void foo()
{
  DEBUG_METHOD("foo");
}

Or, for class methods:

C++
void myclass::foo()
{
  DEBUG_METHOD("myclass::foo");
}

Assuming that DEBUG_METHOD is a macro that somehow outputs an appropriate log string, for example:

C++
#define DEBUG_METHOD(name) std::cout << "-->" << name;

Using the __FUNCTION__ macro

After the update to this article on 2010-03-08, I've added another version of the source project for download. The new version uses a parameter-less version of DEBUG_METHOD, and instead of having the programmer type in the function name (in some cases, complete with the class name as well), it uses a macro provided by the compiler called __FUNCTION__. This is a nifty macro that the compiler keeps updating during compilation so that it always gives the name of the function or class method it is used in. And, thanks to the way C++'s pre-processor resolves macros, it is possible to use a macro within a macro. Neat! At this point, I have to send my thanks to bling who pointed this out to me; thanks man!

(Now, back to the original article text).

To log the method exit might initially seem slightly harder, as a method can exit in several places and in several different ways (it can return or throw an exception). One would not want to add a DEBUG_METHOD_EXIT macro to all places where the method can return, both because it would clutter the code and be tedious to maintain, but because of exceptions, it's impossible to cover all exits.

But if DEBUG_METHOD instead of simply outputting a message also creates an object on the stack, then the deterministic destruction of objects in C++ will guarantee its destructor to be called whenever the scope of that object completes, be it by return or by an exception being thrown. So, by changing the initial macro definition to:

C++
#define DEBUG_METHOD(name) bornander::debug::log _debugLog(name);

this becomes possible. In this case, bornander::debug is the namespace containing the class called log, which is instantiated with _debugLog as a variable name, passing in the method name to its constructor. When the _debugLog object's scope completes, the destructor is called, and it's therefore possible to log both entry and exit using a singe log statement.

The constructor and destructor of the log class look something like (assuming that the method name is stored in a class member called context):

C++
log::log(const std::string& ctx) : context(ctx)
{
  std::cout << "-->" << context << std::endl;
}

log::~log()
{
  std::cout << "<-- " << context << std::endl;
}

This would produce an output (when calling a method called main) that looks like this:

This is all well and good, but in order to show the call chain (or stack depth), this method lacks formatting, as shown below, where main calls foo, which in turns calls bar:

While it is still possible to deduce the call chain, the output formatting doesn't go to any great lengths to make it easy for the user to do so. This can be solved by letting the log class store a static integer holding the stack depth. By converting the stack depth to an indentation, the output can be formatted to show the call chain. Since it is stored in a static member, each instance of the log class simply increments it in its constructor, and decrements it in its destructor. Using this technique, the output becomes more readable:

The logging statements required to get the output above would be something like this:

C++
Shrink ▲   
int bar()
{
  DEBUG_METHOD("bar");

  // Do bar logic

  return 1;
}

void foo()
{
  DEBUG_METHOD("foo");

  switch(bar())
  {
  case 0:
    // Do 0 stuff, and return immediately
    return;
  case 1:
    // Do 1 stuff and continue
    break;
  default:
    throw std::exception("failed");
  }

  // additional logic
}

int main(int /*argc*/, char** /*argv*/)
{
  DEBUG_METHOD("main");

  foo();

  return 0;
}

Notice that regardless of how or where the foo method exists, the log output is the same as the exit output is written on scope completion of the log object instantiated at the top of every method using the DEBUG_METHOD macro.

Execution time

In this debug log, it is also possible to get the method exit output to include the execution time of the logged method (including any of its children). This is done by storing the current time when the log object is instantiated, and then subtracting this from the time of destruction. There are many ways to get a timestamp in C++. I decided to go with the clock() method found in time.h. As including that particular header might not be part of the logged application, it is possible to disable the timing completely, or rather, it has to be explicitly enabled by defining DEBUG_LOG_ENABLE_TIMING.

This yields a constructor/destructor pair for the log class that looks like this:

C++
int log::indentation = 0;
std::ostream* log::stream = &&std::cout;

log::log(const std::string& ctx)
: context(ctx)
#ifdef DEBUG_LOG_ENABLE_TIMING
    , start_time(clock())
#endif
{
    write_indentation();
    *stream << "--> " << context << std::endl;
    ++indentation;
}

log::~log()
{
    --indentation;
    write_indentation(std::uncaught_exception() ? '*' : ' ');
    *stream << "<-- " << context;
#ifdef DEBUG_LOG_ENABLE_TIMING
    *stream << " in " << ((double)(clock() - start_time) / CLOCKS_PER_SEC) << "s";
#endif
*stream << std::endl;
}

The std::ostream* log::stream is another static member holding a reference to the output method, by default set to std::cout. Indentation by stack depth is written using the private helper method write_indentation(), which simply uses the value stored in the static indentation variable to write a couple of spaces to log::stream.

Exception logging

When an exception is thrown, it's good to know how it bubbles up the call stack, especially if it is one that is not going to be caught at all by the application (in the case, of an unexpected exception). A neat function included in STL is std::uncaught_exception(), which returns true if there's currently an uncaught exception alive. In the destructor of the log class, this is called to use an asterisk to indicate that the current method exited because of an exception (as shown in the code example above).

So, in the previous application example, if the bar() method had returned 2 for example, then the output would have looked like this instead (provided that the exception was caught and handled in the main method):

The * character is, in this example, indicating that when the foo() method completed, there was a live exception still uncaught, but as the main() method exit log is not preceded by a *, that exception must have been caught in that method.

Logging value of variables

To get enough information to troubleshoot an issue, both the context (call chain) and the values of the relevant variables need to be logged. Preferably, the logger should be able to log any type of value. To achieve this in a .NET language would have been easy since all objects inherit from System.Object and a textual representation of the value can be retrieved using the ToString() method. C++ does not offer such luxuries, but by using template programming, it is possible to achieve something similar. But the logging value alone is not enough. The value has to have the name as well, and this could have been done by something like:

C++
#define LOG_VARIABLE(name, value) log_variable(name, value);

template<T> void log_variable(const std::string& name, const T& value)
{
  std::cout << name << "=" << value << std::endl;
}

The annoying thing about this is that the programmer is forced to manually name the value when outputting it, which is redundant in most cases since the identifier being logged usually has a name anyway (the name of the variable). To get around this problem, I used the # operator of C++'s pre-processor language, which will yield the name, rather than the value, of a passed parameter:

C++
#define DEBUG_VALUE_OF(variable) { _debugLog.value_of(#variable, variable, false); }

class log
{
  template<class T> void value_of(const std::string& name, 
             const T& value, const bool outputTypeInformation);
};

template<class T> void log::value_of(const std::string& name, 
              const T& value, const bool outputTypeInformation)
{
  write_indentation();

  *stream << name;
#ifdef DEBUG_LOG_ENABLE_TYPE_OUTPUT
  if (outputTypeInformation)
  {
    *stream << "(" << typeid(value).name() << ")";
  }
#endif
  *stream << "=[" << value << "]" << std::endl;
  stream->flush();
}

This allows the programmer to log variables and their values using this syntax:

C++
std::string str = "Hello, world!";
DEBUG_VALUE_OF(str);

And, the output would be (provided support for RTTI was not enabled):

name=[Hello, world!]

The DEBUG_LOG_ENABLE_TYPE_OUTPUT define is to enable/disable outputting of run time type information. This is useful when debugging applications that dynamically instanciate different objects inheriting from a base class, as it allows the logger not to output just the variable, but also the type of it. In most cases, this is not important, and the complex types of C++ makes this a bit messy (always printing the full type information for a simple string is really annoying). Because of this, this simple debug log comes with different macros for debugging variables so that that technique can be used only when necessary.

Collections

By relying on the duck-typing of C++ templates, the values in some collections can also be debugged. In my implementation, this relies on the collection at hand, having things such as size_type and size() defined on them. There are also macros provided to not output all elements in the collection. In case the collection is big, the programmer can say, "I only want to see the top or bottom 8", for example. The macros for the collection value logging looks like this:

C++
#define DEBUG_VALUE_OF_COLLECTION(variable)    
   { _debugLog.value_of_collection(#variable, variable, 0, all, false); }
#define DEBUG_VALUE_OF_TOP_COLLECTION(variable, maxCount) 
   { _debugLog.value_of_collection(#variable, variable, maxCount, top, false); }
#define DEBUG_VALUE_OF_BOTTOM_COLLECTION(variable, maxCount) 
   { _debugLog.value_of_collection(#variable, variable, maxCount, bottom, false); }
#define DEBUG_VALUE_AND_TYPE_OF_COLLECTION(variable) 
   { _debugLog.value_of_collection(#variable, variable, 0, all, true); }
#define DEBUG_VALUE_AND_TYPE_OF_TOP_COLLECTION(variable, maxCount) 
   { _debugLog.value_of_collection(#variable, variable, maxCount, top, true); }
#define DEBUG_VALUE_AND_TYPE_OF_BOTTOM_COLLECTION(variable, maxCount) 
   { _debugLog.value_of_collection(#variable, variable, maxCount, bottom, true); }

In these macros, the all, top, and bottom identifiers are part of an enum used internally by the log class to determine which part of the collection to log. Again, template programming has to be used not only for the duck typing, but like in the case of normal variables, we need to deduce the argument type at compile time. Because of this, the log collection value method looks like this:

C++
Shrink ▲   
template<class T> void log::value_of_collection(
    const std::string& name, 
    const T& collection, 
    const typename T::size_type max, 
    const list_segment segment, 
    const bool outputTypeInformation)
{
  const T::size_type limit = max != 0 ? 
    std::min<T::size_type>(max, collection.size()) : collection.size();

  T::size_type startIndex = 0;
  switch(segment)
  {
  case all:
  case top:
    startIndex = 0;
    break;
  case bottom:
    startIndex = collection.size() - limit;
    break;
  }

  const T::size_type endIndex = startIndex + limit;

  write_indentation();
  *stream << "collection(" << name;
  #ifdef DEBUG_LOG_ENABLE_TYPE_OUTPUT
  if (outputTypeInformation)
  {
    *stream << "(" << typeid(collection).name() << ")";
  }
  #endif
  *stream << ", " << collection.size() 
          << " items)" << std::endl;
  write_indentation();
  *stream << "{" << std::endl;

  if (startIndex != 0)
  {
    write_indentation();
    *stream << "   ..." << std::endl;
  }

  for(T::size_type i = startIndex; i < endIndex; ++i)
  {
    write_indentation();
    *stream << "   [" << i << "]=[" 
            << collection[i] << "]" << std::endl;
  }

  if (endIndex != collection.size())
  {
    write_indentation();
    *stream << "   ..." << std::endl;
  }

  write_indentation();
  *stream << "}" << std::endl;
  stream->flush();
}

Enabling it all

So that it is possible to disable all logging, without rewriting anything, all logging is handled by macros. There are three that turn on/off the features of this logger:

  • DEBUG_LOG_ENABLE
  • DEBUG_LOG_ENABLE_TIMING
  • DEBUG_LOG_ENABLE_TYPE_OUTPUT

The first one is the master-switch for the entire thing, the other two enable the timing of methods and the outputting of type information, respectively. To configure these at project level in Visual Studio, right-click the project and click Properties, Configuration Properties, C/C++, Preprocessor, and Preprocessor directives and simply add these three lines.

Points of interest

In order to successfully log stuff using the left-shift operator on a std::ostream, the logged artifact must support that operator. The primitives and std::string already do, but for custom objects, a friend method has to be declared. This is dead simple, and is explained in detail in parashift's C++ FAQ, chapter 15.8. There's also an example included in the test program in the source code for this article.

To set a different std::ostream than std::cout, simply use the macro DEBUG_SET_STREAM at the beginning of your main method.

C++
DEBUG_SET_STREAM(std::cerr);

Again, this is not an attempt at creating an application log framework, this is something to help in debugging/trouble shooting applications in situations where attaching a debugger might be difficult, and as such, I think it works pretty well, except for performance (it's a bit too slow for my liking).

As always, any comments on the code or the article are most welcome.

History

  • 2010-03-06: First version.
  • 2010-03-08: Added version with the __FUNCTION__ macro.
  • 2010-03-15: Fixed the compilation errors in the Release version.

Hi, nice and elegant solution that fits to my needs. Thanks. What about thread safety? And why do we need this one DEBUG_USING_NAMESPACE as we use only macroses in a client's code
Sign in·View Thread5.00/5 (1 vote) 
Re: Thread safety
Fredrik Bornander23-Jul-12 7:21
Fredrik Bornander23-Jul-12 7:21 
You're right in thinking
C++
Shrink ▲   
DEBUG_USING_NAMESPACE
is redundant, it shouldn't be required at all. I think I've managed to accidentally leave that in there since the code did not use macros for all the calls to the logging functionality. Well spotted!

As for thread safety; it was not considered at all for this article so you'll get weird results if this is run in a threaded application.
I have a thread-safe (for pthreads) implementation lying around somewhere that I've used in the past but the problem with that is that the behaviour of the debug version of the application differs quite a lot from the release due to all the locks.

Thanks for commenting and pointing out the DEBUG_USING_NAMESPACE issue!

/Fredrik Bornander

Re: DEBUG_VALUE_OF supports wchar_t* and BSTR?
Fredrik Bornander28-Jul-11 11:12
Fredrik Bornander28-Jul-11 11:12 
To get it to work with custom types you need to provide a
Shrink ▲   
ostream
left-shift operator implementation for that type.

Something like:

C++
Shrink ▲   
ostream &operator<<(ostream &stream, SomeCustomClass scc)
{
  stream << scc.OneProperty << " ";
  stream << "(" << scc.AnotherProperty << ") ";
  return stream;
}


Google is your friend when it comes to the details[^].

Hope this helps,
Fredrik Bornander

Pretty easy principle but..
nonameqw22-Mar-10 14:01
nonameqw22-Mar-10 14:01 
Nice little tool but i have a few additions for you; The timing part is not very precise. None of my little shortstory application in which the logger was tested i had all but one '<-- in 0s'. If the following could be replaced in the ifdef ___TIMING__ brances, we'd get microsecond precision (actually nanosecond precision, depends on how much it's scaled). Im guessing, but beleive 'clock()' will get floor'ed every 10milliseconds. We end up with 95% 0s output (at least i did )

I found some documentation, the source references on this page should actually also works with windows compiled software:

http://allmybrain.com/2008/06/10/timing-cc-code-on-linux/

Ok, so the difference is using two timestamps and subtracting them;

  • the headerfile place in <sys/time.h> supports 'timeval' and gettimeofday
  • on construct set timeval start_time with gettimeofday(&start_time, NULL);
  • on destruction, lets set an additional timeval stop_time and do gettimeofday
  • timersub(&stop_time,&start_time,&result_time); would subtract time spent during method debugging and
  • *stream << " in " << result_time.tv_sec+result_time.tv_usec/1000000.0 << "s" << std::endl


Its pretty simple, but may include a sligt overhead compared to just calling

change of include


Shrink ▲   
// increasing the presicion will make optimization a little easier and also easier to locate bottlenecks
// resulting sample output of the following changes is for instance
//'MyProgram started'
// --> _show_all
//  <-- _show_all in 4.00344s
#ifdef DEBUG_LOG_ENABLE_TIMING

#include <sys/time.h>
#endif

class member difference


Shrink ▲   
#ifdef DEBUG_LOG_ENABLE_TIMING

	timeval start_time, stop_time, result_time;

#endif

ctor


Shrink ▲   
#ifdef DEBUG_LOG_ENABLE_TIMING

	gettimeofday(&start_time, NULL);
#endif

dtor


Shrink ▲   
#ifdef DEBUG_LOG_ENABLE_TIMING
	gettimeofday(&stop_time, NULL);
	timersub(&stop_time,&start_time,&result_time);
	*stream << " in " << result_time.tv_sec+result_time.tv_usec/1000000.0 << "s";

#endif



Also, there's a quite bit of compiler complaining when trying to output the 'COLLECTION' through templating, i get:
DebugLog.hpp: In member function 'void bornander::debug::log::value_of_collection(const std::string&, const T&, typename T::size_type, bornander::debug::list_segment, bool)':
DebugLog.hpp:102: error: expected `;' before 'startIndex'

where all the indexing sizetypes are defined. I couldnt figure out a solution, please mail me @ morten@msigsgaard.dk - it looks promising

Sign in·View Thread 
Excellent, but I have something to add
valdok15-Mar-10 23:39
valdok15-Mar-10 23:39 
Fredrik,
this is an excellent idea. Since I was also using a similar type of logging/tracing I can confirm that this type of tracing is extremely handy.

But I have two things to comment:

1. Your implementation is not thread-safe. You're using a static indentation variable that is seen and modified in all the threads.

You may wrap your variable with __declspec(thread) semantics, this will access it via the TLS (thread local storage).
(However if you have DLLs - this won't work well. Need to use TlsGetValue/TlsSetValue explicitly).

2. This approach is useful not only for debug tracing. It can also be used in Release build for logging.

If you have time - please read (and comment) my article about this:
Superior logging design. Fast but comprehensive[^]
Sign in·View Thread 
Re: Excellent, but I have something to add
Fredrik Bornander16-Mar-10 3:04
Fredrik Bornander16-Mar-10 3:04 
Hi Valdok,

Thanks for commenting, I'm glad you liked the article and thanks for your suggestions.


valdok wrote:
1. Your implementation is not thread-safe. You're using a static indentation variable that is seen and modified in all the threads.


If I were to implement this in a thread safe manner, I would create a dictionary for the indentation where the thread id was the key, that way, each thread would have it's own indentation (which, to me, make more sense as well).

This would obviously require the std::ostream to be thread safe as well. This causes problems as it would require to introduce too much locking just to get the logging right, I believe it would interfere substantially with the application logic.

valdok wrote:
2. This approach is useful not only for debug tracing. It can also be used in Release build for logging.


Agreed, all though I would probably use a proper logging framework for that, with levels and different log targets.

valdok wrote:
If you have time - please read (and comment) my article about this:


Will do as soon as I get home from work.

/Fredrik
Sign in·View Thread 
Re: Excellent, but I have something to add
supercat916-Mar-10 5:58
supercat916-Mar-10 5:58 
Fredrik Bornander wrote:
This would obviously require the std::ostream to be thread safe as well.


Perhaps the thing to do would be to have a thread-safe class to queue logging events, which could then be output via suitable means by a separate thread. I've never really done much with C++ (I use .net) but it's interesting to see that the "antiquated" language has some features that the new ones can't touch.

Fredrik Bornander16-Mar-10 6:25

Sign in·View Thread 
Re: Excellent, but I have something to add
supercat916-Mar-10 9:19
supercat916-Mar-10 9:19 
Fredrik Bornander wrote:
You'd be surprised of what you can do with C++


Indeed, it can do many things, though there are some definite advantages to the managed-code world. For objects which do neither use unmanaged resources nor service events, garbage-collection is often better than explicit allocation/deallocation. Unfortunately, objects which use unmanaged resources or service events require explicit cleanup code since there's no inherent mechanism to deal with it. If .net had supported weak delegates from the get-go, the situation wouldn't be so bad since data observers could subscribe to update events using weak delegates to themselves; if the observer wasn't needed by anything other than its update events, it could then be garbage-collected. As it is, though, it can be difficult to avoid leaking subscriptions, thus effectively leaking memory.
Sign in·View Thread 
Re: Excellent, but I have something to add
Fredrik Bornander16-Mar-10 22:53
Fredrik Bornander16-Mar-10 22:53 
Agreed. We've run into (and solved) the issue with leaking subscriptions where I work now, but it's a weird case because you tend not to look for leaks in a garbage collected world.

These day's I don't get to do any C++ (except in my own time of course), I kind of miss it as I really like it, but I prefer the managed world as it lets me be more productive. What I really miss from C++ is its template system, duck-typing FTW!

/Fredrik

Re: Excellent, but I have something to add
supercat917-Mar-10 16:14
supercat917-Mar-10 16:14 
I wish C# had included somewhat more macro facilities, scaling up those in C/C++ rather than scaling them back. Some things can be done with macros that really can't be done other ways, though the C/C++ macro processors do have some pretty severe limitations.

It's funny that Microsoft decided to include some features in vb.net but not C# and vice versa; I use vb.net but there have been times I've wished for C# features. On the other hand, I think if I used C# I would miss some vb.net features.

Question
bilo8115-Mar-10 7:17
bilo8115-Mar-10 7:17 
Top stuff, 5 for me.

Just a quick one, I've downloaded your example and I think you need to add inside
#ifndef DEBUG_LOG_ENABLE
...
...
#define DEBUG_MESSAGE(debug_message)<--- THIS LINE

otherwise compile error occurs if DEBUG_LOG_ENABLE is not defined.

Cheers man and keep up the good work.

Sign in·View Thread 
Simple and Effective
Bill Gord8-Mar-10 9:00
Bill Gord8-Mar-10 9:00 
I have always been a supporter of simple, efficient, effective debug logs; dating back into the early '70s and wonderfully slow mainframes, these little logs have kept me sane and ahead of the game.

Experience always reminds me that clients don't really want to see the debug log. If they do (or think they do), creeping feature-ism leaps forward like a speeding bullet, so it is always a good idea to have a 'system-log' scheduled and costed into any system where the end-client may have logging needs.

Great article! I even found a quick addition to my own logger class - using
Shrink ▲   
std::uncaught_exception()
in the logging DTOR.

Thanks
Sign in·View Thread
